{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3488490,"name":"AfterTen","username":"AfterTen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/afterten/{size}/11780_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T22:15:30.843Z","cooked":"

I’m driving a real swerve robot and using the AdvantageKit SparkSwerve Template as the base for the swerve code. Minimal changes have been made to the template.

The issue is when I push up on the joystick the real robot moves forward and drives normally. Same with side to side.

But when watching in AdvantageScope, when pushing up (+X) robot moves to the right (-Y).

Also concerning, but looking to just fix the orientation issue first, is the visualization of the robot in AS is very slow even though the robot is moving at max speed (around 3.2 meters/s).

At a loss here.

Here’s a little example from one of my logs

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-20T22:15:30.843Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":59,"reads":150,"readers_count":149,"score":325.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":482795,"topic_slug":"advantagekit-odometry-mis-match-things-look-opposite","display_username":"AfterTen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27113,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3572 Wavelength - Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/advantagekit-odometry-mis-match-things-look-opposite/482795/1","custom_user_title":"3572 Wavelength - Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3488507,"name":"Andy Gasser","username":"gdefender","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gdefender/{size}/168507_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T22:26:19.939Z","cooked":"

If you add a link to your code we can take a look. Most likely you have a coordinate error, where X and Y are swapped. You say “when pushing up (+X)” but pushing away from you on a joystick is (-Y) so it’s not clear what you’re doing. It would be correct that “up” on the field image on the left would be (+X).

Take a look at the WPILib Coordinate System page and see if you can spot how what you have is different from what’s expected.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-21T05:52:00.078Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":80,"readers_count":79,"score":21.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":482795,"topic_slug":"advantagekit-odometry-mis-match-things-look-opposite","display_username":"Rishi Desai","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57090,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Head Programming for 7451"},"post_url":"/t/advantagekit-odometry-mis-match-things-look-opposite/482795/4","custom_user_title":"Head Programming for 7451","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3488858,"name":"AfterTen","username":"AfterTen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/afterten/{size}/11780_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T13:48:51.059Z","cooked":"

This is not really new code. The physical robot drives perfectly fine.
It’s fast and drives in the direction you want when operating the joysticks.
The pigeon is dead center of the robot and is initialized to zero on startup so whatever direction the robot is facing is downfield.

This is using last years robot with new code base but still very similar to last year since we started with the AK template as well. Last years robot, all was well.

Ran the characterization tests got the values for Ks and Kv.
Square robot so SwerveDriveKinematics are pretty straight forward.

I’m just not getting the disconnect between the the Swerve tab showing the Measured SwerveChassisSpeeds data, which is perfectly normal and poseestimation showing the robot driving opposite and slow.

This our 3rd year on swerve and AK/AS so none of the setup and operation is really new.

Just didn’t know if anyone had seen this before.

Team has robot tore apart right now for refurbishment. Once it’s drivable again I may just start from scratch and slowly add back in my modifications and see what starts tripping it up.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-21T13:48:51.059Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":60,"readers_count":59,"score":17.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":482795,"topic_slug":"advantagekit-odometry-mis-match-things-look-opposite","display_username":"AfterTen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57090,"username":"rdesai14","name":"Rishi Desai","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/3ab097/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27113,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3572 Wavelength - Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/advantagekit-odometry-mis-match-things-look-opposite/482795/5","custom_user_title":"3572 Wavelength - Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3494016,"name":"AfterTen","username":"AfterTen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/afterten/{size}/11780_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-27T20:52:46.088Z","cooked":"

This will probably be a little long winded but I always like to follow up on my own posts after I solve them. This will probably never apply to anyone else.

The Mechanical Advantage swerve template for SparkMax they subtract the swerve module zero offset from the SparkMax encoder value every periodic loop as it updates the input.

github.com

Mechanical-Advantage/AdvantageKit/blob/1e9826bde9cfc39da8ec98556c20c42526e89938/template_projects/sources/spark_swerve/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/drive/ModuleIOSpark.java#L197


      
    
          
  1.     new DoubleSupplier[] {driveSpark::getAppliedOutput, driveSpark::getBusVoltage},
    2. 
          
  2.     (values) -> inputs.driveAppliedVolts = values[0] * values[1]);
    3. 
          
  3. ifOk(driveSpark, driveSpark::getOutputCurrent, (value) -> inputs.driveCurrentAmps = value);
    4. 
          
  4. inputs.driveConnected = driveConnectedDebounce.calculate(!sparkStickyFault);
    5. 
          
  5. 
          
  6. // Update turn inputs
    7. 
          
  7. sparkStickyFault = false;
    8. 
          
  8. ifOk(
    9. 
          
  9.     turnSpark,
    10. 
          
  10.     turnEncoder::getPosition,
    11. 
          
  11.     (value) -> inputs.turnPosition = new Rotation2d(value).minus(zeroRotation));
    12. 
          
  12. ifOk(turnSpark, turnEncoder::getVelocity, (value) -> inputs.turnVelocityRadPerSec = value);
    13. 
          
  13. ifOk(
    14. 
          
  14.     turnSpark,
    15. 
          
  15.     new DoubleSupplier[] {turnSpark::getAppliedOutput, turnSpark::getBusVoltage},
    16. 
          
  16.     (values) -> inputs.turnAppliedVolts = values[0] * values[1]);
    17. 
          
  17. ifOk(turnSpark, turnSpark::getOutputCurrent, (value) -> inputs.turnCurrentAmps = value);
    18. 
          
  18. inputs.turnConnected = turnConnectedDebounce.calculate(!sparkStickyFault);
    19. 
          
  19. 
          
  20. // Update odometry inputs
    21. 
          
  21. inputs.odometryTimestamps =
    22.

I don’t like that. I like my logged values to represent raw data and not calculated data even if that calculation is simply the raw data minus a constant.

So, when I implemented this template into my own code I switched it so that when the robot starts it resets the SparkMax encoder to the the value it should be given the value of the offset and the current rotation of the module wheel.
This allows me to get rid of that .minus in line 197 and just record the raw value of the position of the SparkMax.

But I forgot to see where else that zero rotation is applied.
Once I looked for it I found it in the code that feeds the odometry thread that ends up being used to calculate the robot pose.

github.com

Mechanical-Advantage/AdvantageKit/blob/1e9826bde9cfc39da8ec98556c20c42526e89938/template_projects/sources/spark_swerve/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/drive/ModuleIOSpark.java#L213


      
    
          
  1.   ifOk(turnSpark, turnSpark::getOutputCurrent, (value) -> inputs.turnCurrentAmps = value);
    2. 
          
  2.   inputs.turnConnected = turnConnectedDebounce.calculate(!sparkStickyFault);
    3. 
          
  3. 
          
  4.   // Update odometry inputs
    5. 
          
  5.   inputs.odometryTimestamps =
    6. 
          
  6.       timestampQueue.stream().mapToDouble((Double value) -> value).toArray();
    7. 
          
  7.   inputs.odometryDrivePositionsRad =
    8. 
          
  8.       drivePositionQueue.stream().mapToDouble((Double value) -> value).toArray();
    9. 
          
  9.   inputs.odometryTurnPositions =
    10. 
          
  10.       turnPositionQueue.stream()
    11. 
          
  11.           .map((Double value) -> new Rotation2d(value).minus(zeroRotation))
    12. 
          
  12.           .toArray(Rotation2d[]::new);
    13. 
          
  13.   timestampQueue.clear();
    14. 
          
  14.   drivePositionQueue.clear();
    15. 
          
  15.   turnPositionQueue.clear();
    16. 
          
  16. }
    17. 
          
  17. 
          
  18. @Override
    19. 
          
  19. public void setDriveOpenLoop(double output) {
    20. 
          
  20.   driveSpark.setVoltage(output);
    21. 
          
  21. }
    22.

Just has to get rid of that .minus and all issues were resolved.
